Muller reveals that tuition increase is forthcoming
By BOB BUCHANAN
President Muller and
University fiscal officers met
with the Budget and Audit
Committee of the Board of
Trustees yesterday to discuss the
size of an almost certain tuition
hike for next year.

e

$

President Muller

"It is evident for obvious
reasons that some increase in
tuition will be necessary," Muller
stated yesterday.
The tuition rise would be the
second in as many years for
students here, coming at a time
when other private institutions
are considering similar increases
in response to unprecedented
educational cost outlays.
Muller emphasized that no
final decision was reached at
yesterday's meeting, which was
intended to allow members to
express different points of view.
Such meetings are designed to aid
Muller in making a final decision
on the size of the tuition increase
he will propose to the full Board
of Trustees in December-.
University Budget Director
Norman Krueger and Vice
President for Business
Management Robert Bowie
prepared the President's
presentation to the Budget and

Audit Committee. Krueger
reserved comment on the content
of their findings.
Krueger said that the results of
yesterday's meeting will be
conveyed to the President's Ad
Hoc Budgetary Committee,
appointed last year to assist in

Bernstein to open Symposium
By LAINY STEPHANS
The ninth annual Milton S.
Eisenhower Symposium will
open October 6 ,with Carl
Bernstein, the Washington Post
reporter who helped break the
Watergate scandal, delivers the
first address of this year's
topi,_"The Pen as the Sword,
Dynamics of the Written Media."
Chaired by seniors Joachim
Blunck, James Brown, and Peter
Yancone, the Symposium will
feature speeches, interviews, and
media presentations by such
journalists as Russell Baker,
Seymour Hersh. David
Fhlberstam and Shana Alexander.
"We wanted to have 'a
legitimate Symposium—and to do
that we had to touch all the bases
in the media," said Blunck. He
explained that ,the opening
Speaker, Carl Bernstein, who
along with Bob Woodward delved
into the Watergate burglary, was
selected for his role in
investigative reporting.
Berstein will be followed by
Hunter S. Thompson, chief of
the national affairs. desk of
Rolling Stone, and the author of
the Fear and Loathing series.
Thompson, who will be
interviewed by the three
chairmen, was invited because of
his role in "new journalism." He
will appear October 9.
Stan Lee, publisher of Marvel
Comics and the man responsible
for such characters as Spiderman,
the Fantastic Four, Thor, and the
Hulk, will visit Hopkins October
13.
New York Times columnist
and the author of a regular
feature, "The Sunday Observer,"
Russell Baker will return to his
alma mater on October 22.
Blunck said that Baker, a
former News-Letter editor who
was selected for the Symposium
because of "his regular social
satire," has said he would rather
be interviewed through
Previously prepared questions
than present a formal speech.
Another Times staffer, Pulitzer
Prize-winning correspondent and
former chief of their Saigon
bureau, David Halberstam, will
address audiences in Shriver Hall

Peter Yancone, Jim Brown, Joachim Blunck

proposed Ethics Code will
become official University
governance for academic offense.
The final draft of the proposal,
which was approved last week by
the Student Council and the
Academic Council, is the result
of four months of deliberation
and revision by a student-faculty
task force.
Though the document in its
original form was approved in a
student referendum last April,
the Student Council decided
Wednesday that the changes
made over the summer by the
task force were significant
enough to warrant resubmitting
the proposal to a student vote.
Academic administrators and
the students who worked on the
modification of the Ethics Code
last summer said yesterday that
the revisions made were not
major and that the pridiple of
student-faculty cooperation has
remained intact.
"The original referendum
really approved the Ethics Code
in priniciple," said Sigmund
Suskind, Dean of Graduate and
Undergraduate Programs. "That
document was by no means
immutable. It was clear that it
would need work in some areas."
The task force—comprised of
Professors Roger Horn, John

Sigmund Suskind
Gryder, teptien Roth, and
A . J.R. Russell-Wood, and
undergraduates Peter Gregory,
Dan Holik, Joan McDermott, and
Robert Poynter—was charged
with rewriting the original
document in the form of a
constitution and improving the
clarity and feasibility of some of
its provisions.
The major change made by the
group was the elimination of a
degree scale for academic
violations. Under the revised
version, penalties are set at the
discretion of the hearing board

Graduate enrollment continues to decline
While the University's
undergraduate student body has
been steadily growing for the
past several years, graduate
student enrollment has
plummeted over the same peribd
of time, a trend which has given
some Hopkins administrators and
faculty cause for concern.
The number of graduate
students has gone down from a
high of 1309 in the Fall 1969
semester to the present
enrollment of936.
Though Homewood's
department chairmen contend
that the decrease has not had any
adverse impact on graduate
programs, research, or
undergraduate instruction, some
have expressed concern for the
trend's long term implications.
The downward spiral arises in
large part from the loss of a
substantial amount of
government funds for graduate
study over the past four years.
Most of the government's
Training Grant fellowships for

graduate study, as well as
numerous National Science
Foundation and National
Institute of Health subsidy
programs, have been terminated.
"The drop in graduate
enrollment is directly
attributable to the drying up of
government money," said Larry
Denton, director of Academic
Services. "In the heyday of
contracts and fellowships,
Hopkins could afford to
subsidize loads of graduate-level
educations. That's no longer
possible."
While numerous Homewood
departments operated with
Training Grants several years ago,
only four—Social Relations,
Psychology, Biology, and
Physics—have survived the
government cutbacks with their
grants intact.
Most departments, however,
appear able to cope with the
reduction in graduate students.
Dr. Willis Gore, Chairman of
Electrical Engineering, said that

faculty members in his
department have "picked up the
slack" in regard to undergraduate
section teaching, which is
normally the duty of graduate
students.
"In a conscientious
department, the faculty will help
make ends meet," he explained.
"We have not been adversely
affected by the overall drop in
enrollment, though we may if
this trend continues."
Dr. Brown Murr, head of
Chemistry, said that his
department's graduate programs
have not been impaired by
reduced enrollment, since the
size of the Chemistry faculty
itself has gone down from 22 to
18 in recent years. "We have less
graduate students than before,
but this was a deliberate decision
on the part of our faculty, to go
along with the reduction in our
full-time faculty, he explained.
Murr said that undergraduate
Chemistry majors are now being
used as lab assistants, a position

formerly reserved for graduate
students.
Murr and Gore both said that
they fear faculty members may
someday have to "pick up the
slack" of undergraduate teaching
at the expense of their research,
if the downward trend in
enrollment continues. "This is a
trend which should give all
faculty members cause to wonder
about the coming years in higher
education," Gore stated.
In their efforts to maintain a
stable enrollment despite the loss
of federal funds, departments are
trying to enroll more graduate
students capable of paying their
own tuition, according to Dean
of Arts and Sciences George
Owen.
Owen asserted, though, that
the financial status of an
applicant will not affect his
chances for graduate admission.
"We've been getting more paying
students because we've been
trying to force more of them to
pay their own way," he said.

self-addressed stamped envelope s

COMMUNITY NEWS

City Fair: better than ever, but not necessarily bigger
Over one and a half million
people are expected to flock to
the Inner Harbor this weekend to
take part in the sixth annual
Baltimore City Fair.
Volunteers from 72
neighborhood associations, 115
non-profit organizations, and 15
ethnic groups will be on hand to
welcome and entertain* the
throngs that will pack the Harbor
area at Pratt and Light Streets.
In addition to the many
volunteer organizations that will
be present, professional
entertainment will also be
Provided during the weekend
festivities. Concerts, featuring
Two Generations of Brubeck,
Barbara McNair, and the
Maynard Ferguson Big Band will
be offered throughout the three
days, as well as performances by
the U.S. Army Golden Knights
Parachute Team and the Flying
Bilros.
The Fair hours are noon to 10
p.m. Friday, 10 a.m. to 10 p.m.
Saturday, and noon to 10 p.m.
Sunday. Admission is $1.25.
A park and ride service
operated by the MTA will be
Operated from three locations in

the city. The lower parking lot
on Wyman Park Drive and
Remington Avenue will serve as
one of the Park and Ride
stations. Buses will run at 20
minute intervals from the parking
lot to the Fair and back.
As in past years, Hopkins will
have an exhibit at the fair.
Volunteers from various
organizations will talk to
fairgoers about the activities at
the Hopkins institutions.
The theme for the Hopkins
exhibit is the University's
Centennial. A wood mobile
representing the Hopkins
commemorative Centennial
Crystal will hang 26 feet in the
air over the Hopkins exhibit. The
free-swinging mobile was
designed by Theo Anderson of
the Accent Display Company.
The Hopkins exhibit will be
located on the Fairgrounds near
the McCormick Spice Building.
At the request of the Fair
committee, Hopkins will also set
up five water fountains on tile
fairground, as it did last year.
According to Dea Kline,
Director of Community Affairs,
"Hopkins has always been very

supportive of the fair concept."
Kline, who continues to serve
on the Fair steering committee as
she has in the past, said that
Hopkins was the first institution
to sign-up for the Fair this year.
Kline asserted that this year
people from all over the East
Coast are likely to attend, many
to observe the Fair and bring
back ideas for sponsoring similar
fairs in their own cities and
communities.

necessarily bigger," Kline said.
Last year's crowds of over one
and a half million taxed the
limits of the Fairground's
capacity.

Keck solves bureaucracy woes
By RUSS SMITH
Residents of the Greater
Homewood area may now have a
method of solving the problems
they encounter in dealing with
Baltimore's mass bureaucracy.
Donna Keck, Mayor's
Representative at the Greater
Homewood Community
Corporation (GHCC), is
sponsoring "Training Sessions on
City Government," a series of
discussions designed to educate
citizens on the mechanics of city
government, and inform them of
the many services available in
Baltimore.
In addition, Keck has
Published a booklet entitled
"The City and the CoMmunity,"
a manual which is "intended as
an aid in solving community
problems and in obtaining city
services." Copies of the guide are,
distributed during meetings of
local civic associations such as
the Remington Improvement
Association. Sign-up sheets for
Keck's training sessions are
circulated at the community
meetings.
The idea for the program was
conceived almost two years ago
by workers at the GHCC who felt
that people in the Greater
Homewood vicinity needed an

in its drive to revitalize the
downtown area. The first fair of
its kind in any city in the
country, the Fair immediately
drew its strength from the many
neighborhoods and ethnic groups
that have in the past keepthe city
segregated into different groups.

Charles Village a redone neighborhood
By PATRICE GALLAGHER
Whether they know it or not,
Hopkins students living off
campus are probably living in the
Charles Village, which
encompasses Greenmount
Avenue, to Howard Street, from
33rd to 23rd Streets. This
information comes from Charles
Kelly, president of the Charles
Village Civic Association.
Kelly is a gregarious young
man who seemed delighted to
talk about the community, its
members, and the projects that
the Civic Association is working
on.
"The community has enough
clout to get just about anything
done," he announced. "We're
composed of a very political
group—people who know their
legislatures, and are very active.
We have lots of teachers, city
planners, young lawyers,
students—a real conglomeration

of people."

would have on the University.
Most important, the school would be pr4cing itself out of
the market of higher .education. True, Hopkins would still be
in the same price range as Harvard,.Yale, etc., but will have
realistically placed itself out of the reach of. many people.
Even more so than today, a Hopkins education will only be
available to the student who is willing to make an
extraordinary financial commitment.
It seems incongrous that an institution such as Hopkins
which prides itself in being unique in so many ways would
fail to remain unique on this crucial point: accessibility to
anyone interested in serious learning.
We are convinced that there are long-range as well as
short-term methods to avoid a tuition hike. Solutions such as
ancillary personnel cutbacks, cutbacks in the more frivolous t
student services. iind the establishment of a tuition
endowment must be considered to prevent Hopkins 1,
froingoing
Auschwitz "a shame".
The Council didn't like the
proposal. Nor did Dean Suskind,
to whose office it entrusted a
host of piddling responsibilities
better suited to a Liverpool
truant officer than to the
University's second highest
academic administrator.
What's more, the thing wasn't
legally viable. University lawyers
advised that Hopkins could well
be entrenched in litigation until
its Tricentennial if that proposal
ever got through. And to be sure,
the Dean's Office had had
enough legal hassles with the
supposedly air-tight Honor
System. So, not wanting the ghost
of Blackstone himself to descend
on Homewood House, Suskind
told the committee to go back to
the Student Council.
The Student Council told the
committee to go out and get
some proof Faculty weren't too
happy about having a venerable
old institution done away with
by some self-appointed student
inquisitors on the basis of a vague
and unsubstantiated "feeling"
that cheating had reached
dangerous proportions. And get
proof they did.
Poll
The committee, on its two
week research furlough,
conducted an anonymous poll of
students in large science survey
courses, which asked the
students, among other questions,
if they had ever cheated on an
exam at Hopkins. The results
were staggering. A terribly high,
embarrassingly high percentage
admitted to having cheated. The
Baltimore Sun picked up on it.
The News American picked up
on it. Faculty members spoke in
hushed tones of the demise of
the Honor System.
One member of the Physics
faculty reportedly suggested that
all the students who had
confessed to cheating be
apprehended and penalized
appropriately. It was pointed out
that the survey was anoymous,
and that no matter how
sophisticated the techniques of
detection, the handwriting on the
ballots would surely not admit of
any conclusive deducation
concerning individuality.
One member of the committee
theorized that perhaps the
students who had admitted to
cheating were not really guilty.
Was not confession akin to
absolution, he inquired. Were
they really guilty?
Yeah, they were guilty; guilty
as hell. So the Student Council

had proof on its hands—along
with 2, alarmed faculty
members who were demanding
that the governance for academic
offenses be revised with alacrity.
So the Student Council sent out
a new committee, comprised of
most of the members of the old
committee and some interested
and respected professors, to find
a viable alternative to the Honor
System. The rhetoric of the new
committee abounded with such
terms as viability, feasibility,
legality, effectuality, and
integrity.
This was to be an efficient
committee which would produce
an acceptable alternative, and
with due haste. For the end of
school was waxing near, and the
whole matter would have to be
put to student referendum before
summer recess. So the new
committee burnt the midnight oil
to come up with an alternative
before the end of the semester.
And they did it. And it went to
student referendum. And the
students passed it. And all was
"as it was before..."
Except that it just wouldn't
do. The proposal was too ragged,
too vague in regard to legal
technicalities; in general, too
hastily compiled. It would have
to be rewritten. So the Student
Council and the Academic
Council, which was by now
immersed in the turmoil, sent out
a "task force" to rewrite the
document.
So eight good students and
professors did spend their
summer and early fall working on
the alternative, perhaps
wondering occasionally whence
the need for this effort had
sprang.
But now that they're done, the
document will have to go back to
student referendum, because it's
a different document than the
one the students passed last
spring.
And it's precisely here that a
harrowing possibility arises.
Suppose the students don't pass
it. Suppose out of ignorance,
disinterest, or sheer funk, they
vote it down. Then those six
months of work. which began so
unportentously back in February
with a two-week committee, will
have been for naught!!
Should the referendum pass or
not:this week's vote will dispose
at one stroke of the controversy
and concern over the alternative
to the Honor System. And when
it's all over, Gilman Hall itself
will likely heave an audible sigh
of relief

his strongest emotional

Greeley, who didn't coin the

but rather managed to run it into

Inspired by Horace's famous

work somehow into (Lis

walked out of the convention

a fifteen-mile Iiike,they tired and

where they wound up. Such was
the founding of the town of
Catonsville, Maryland. Horace,
despite all the hoopla of the
convention and the defection to
his side of a segment of the
Republican party, didn't do too
well against Grant in the general
election. The fact that Horace
died before the election was held
probably had something to do

want to?
Vale, Baltimore
The Panic of 1873, following
close behind the death of
Greeley, devastated Baltimore
businesses. Desperate times
brought forth desperate schemes.
Urban historian James Breslin has
recently discovered the diary of
Baltimore mayor Ferdinand
Latrobe, in which the mayor
describes how a professional
arsonist, Marvin the Torch, gave
the city council the idea for the
-Great Baltimore Fire. "There's
no way business will improve,.'
Marvin told the people's
representatives. "You better cut
your losses while you can and
collect your insurance money.
That's where I come in. You see
this central business
district—(Marvin pointed out the
window of City Hall)—I'm gonna
take it and build you an empty
lot!"
Marvin's proposal was relayed
to the Board of Estimates, which
body decided the Torch's price
was too high. The city would be
better off hiring a local amateur
to do the job on the city. The
Board's recommendation was
sent back to the council for
debate in the summer of 1875.
After extensive debate, the city
fathers decided upon a plan of
action. It was now 1904—five
other depressions had since made
their mark since Greeley's

Eisenhower Library
operating new system
The clarity•••is vastly improved'
Early in September the
Eisenhower Library began
Operating its new computerized
circulation system. The system
consists of a minicomputer,
keyboard display units (CRTs)
and light-pen terminals for
recording charges and discharges.
Each book which circulates will
have affixed to it a bar-encoded
label which, through the
computer data base, records the
essential information about the
volume. In addition another label
on the patron's ID card records
information about that user.
In order to charge out a book
the user presents his or her ID
card and the books wanted at the
Circulation Desk. The light pen is
then drawn over the labels and all
information necessary to charge
the book is thus recorded in the
system and instantly retrievable.

Much the same process is
followed in discharging books
except that reservations or
"holds" for other readers are
automatically signalled by the
terminals.
Advantages
There are several advantages to
the system including more
up-to-date inforrn'ation on the
status of the books, a better
system for reserving books for
other readers, improved security,
and lower cost. The transition
between systems, however, is not
an easy one and has caused some
delay at the Circulation Desk.
Although the staff has
"converted" over 60,000
volumes for use through the new
system, other volumes have to be
converted on the spot by
photocopying of title pages and
recording of call numbers.

"We were torn as to how much

The task force also made

document's clarity as well as its
legal viability. On the
recommendations of the
University's general counsel, the
panel was forced to make
changes in the proposal last week
just prior to its submission to the
SC and the Academic Council.
Integrity
The essential provisons of the
Code have not been altered. The
student-faculty "Academic
Integrity Board" is still charged
with maintaining "the academic
integrity of the Johns Hopkins
University in all respects."
As in the original document,
proctoring is an optional stricture
which may be invoked by faculty

Joachim Blunck

at their own discretion or at the
request of students. Students are
encouraged, though not required,
to report offenses to the Review
Board.
"The clarity of the proposal is
vastly improved and the penalties
are much more clearly
expressed," commented Suskind.
"The absence of a strong punitive
tone gives me a feeling that this is
a damn good document and that
it will work."
SC President Mike Lenardo
also considers the Code an
effective method of governance,
and much improved from its
original state.
Said Holik, "I support the
document, though I feel that it
represents a lot of compromise."

Hopkins eleven bow in scrimmage marred by death
By STEPHEN LEVIN
The Hopkins football team
gained their first taste of
inter-collegiate action, when
Coach Dennis Cox's gridders
travelled to Lebanon Valley on
Saturday for a scrimmage with
the Flying Dutchmen.
The contest took on a
somewhat eerie glow and the
game itself became somewhat
secondary when tragedy struck
near the end of the first quarter.

One of the officials suddenly
collapsed and died on the field,
having suffered -a heart attack.
Despite the pall which this cast
over the action, the game
continued and the
Pennsylvanians emerged
victorious, outscoring the Blue
Jays three touchdowns to two, in
a game played under simulated
game conditions which excluded
kick-offs and returns.
"At this point I would say that

we are definitely stronger
offensively and defensively,"
noted Coach Cox. "We have a lot
more returning people on offense
and a lot more holes to fill on
defense."
The Jays use a multiple
offense with sophomore Dave
Emala at the helm.
"In our offense the
quarterback has to be able to run
as well as throw," said Cox,"and
Dave can do that. He hasn't quite

Rooters take five out offive
By DAVID KRAUS
The JHU Varsity soccer team
upped their pre-season record to
8-2-1 by defeating five area
opponents this past weekend.
The Blue Jay booters began
their successes Friday afternoon
with a 6-1 decision over Dundalk
Community College and closed
out Sunday with four
consecutive victories at the Essex
Community College Soccer
Festival.
Friday's contest was played at
Homewood on a rain-soaked
field. The home team starters
included goalie Greg Bradley,
defensemen Ami Cohen, Frank
Olszewski and Lou Podrazik,
. midfielders Gary Ignatowski,
Tom Myrick and Bob Teasd ale,
and a forward line of Steve
Galloway, Joe Rutkowski, Greg
Cunningham and Larry
McGowan.,
Hopkins took early command
of the game and scored the first
goal midway through the first
period. McGowan, playing left
wing, centered the ball toCunningham, who shot it past
the goalie.
The rest of the first half was
closely played with both teams
having good opportunities, but
failing to cash in on them.
The Blue Jays broke the game
open in the third quarter, scoring

three times while holding their
visitors to a lone goal.
Ken Seuss scored what proved
to be the game winner just five
minutes into the third stanza
when he looped one over the
Dundalk netminder. The visitors
got their only tally of the day a
minute later when a penalty shot
trickled off the hands of goalie
Bradley and into the net.
Coach Robert Oliver's charges
put the game out of reach with
two quick goals at the end of the
period. Rutkowski and
Cunningham scored within three
minutes of each other, the latter
coming with just twenty seconds
remaining in the quarter.
A brief melee occured early in
the final period and a frustrated
Dundalk defenseman was asked
to leave the game. Myrick and
Galloway then proceeded to put
the final nails in the Dundalk
coffin, tallying the final two Blue
Jay goals.
Coach Oliverssaid that it was
"good to play under these lousy
conditions. This is the type of
thing we'll face during the regular
season and it's nice to get used to
it now."
By contrast, Sunday was a
beautiful day, but the game
results were equally favorable for
the Homewood booters.

Tennis team looking
towards strong year
By JOHN GIGLIO
When you talk to Coach Joyce
Hogan these days about how the
Hopkins' Women's tennis team is
shaping up, she'll nod and break
into a smile.
Why? One word: talent.
This year's racquet-wielding
Blue Jays are loaded \Mill it.
They'll be heading into MAC and
MA IAW League competition
with a solid nucleus of
experienced veterans plus a
surprisingly well-schooled bunch
of hard-playing freshmen.
All five starting singles players
from last year's team: Cathy
Cramer, Sandy Ciciora, Susan
Thomas, Lisa Kuhar, and Gwen
Pavlovitz are back to hammer
away at the likes of Goucher and
Franklin and Mafshall, to of
Hopkins' toughest opponents.
Joining them will be a host of
first year players. Three that
really shine on the courts are
Kate Foster, Beth Yanowitz, and
Nancy Tang. Their coach is
especially high on them because
of their outstanding play and
skills displayed so far during

practice along with their fine
records as high school and
tournament players. Two other
girls that have caught the coach's
eye with their strong doubles
play are Lisa Turgell and Anne
Caston.
Positions
The team has been working
out every day since Sept. 8 and
because of the large number of
experienced and talented players
the team carries, Coach Hogan
has said she has "been able to
concentrate more on the strategy
of each individual player's game,
along with setting up shots and
positioning for the doubles
candidates."
We will soon see just how
strong their play is for their first
match is scheduled for this
Thursday, Sept. 18 at home, 4
pm against Notre Dame.
Although declining when
asked to make any predictions,
Coach Hogan's enthusiasm and
optimism was unmistakable. A
seasoned group of veterans
together with a batch of bright
young players spells WINNER!

Lax stars to shine Saturday
The Third Annual Super Star
Lacrosse game will be held on
Homewood Field Saturday, Sept.
20 at 8:30 pm., giving
newcomers to Hopkins their first
look at the mightiest of sports at
Homewood. The game is being
organized by the Lacrosse
Foundation, formerly known as
the Hall of Fame.
The best of the colleges will
challenge the best of the clubs in
this charity contest, the proceeds
of which will go to the Lacrosse
Foundation. In the past, funds
have been used to send players to
the World Series of Lacrosse held
in Australia in 1974. The next
World Series is scheduled for
Manchester, England in 1978.
Among the collegiates will be
three members of the Blue Jay
ten. Attackmen Franz

Wittelsberger and Mike O'Neil
along with goalie Kevin Mahon
will represent Hopkins.
The clubmen will be trying to
capture their first victory in this
seric, having dropped both of
the previous contests.
Tix
Tickets for adults are $3.00 at
the gate and $2.00 in advance.

Children's tickets are $2.00 at
the door and $1.00 in advance.
All tickets can be purchased from
the Lacrosse Foundation which is
located in the Lacrosse Hall of
Fame in the Newton H. White
Athletic Center; as well as at
Bacharach-Rasin, Triangle, and
STX sporting good stores and at
the Crease Restaurant in Towson.

the students who worked on the
modification of the Ethics Code
last summer said yesterday that
the revisions made were not
major and that the pridiple of
student-faculty cooperation has
remained intact.
"The original referendum
really approved the Ethics Code
in priniciple," said Sigmund
Suskind, Dean of Graduate and
Undergraduate Programs. "That
document was by no means
immutable. It was clear that it
would need work in some areas."
The task force—comprised of
Professors Roger Horn, John

Sigmund Suskind
Gryder, teptien Roth, and
A . J.R. Russell-Wood, and
undergraduates Peter Gregory,
Dan Holik, Joan McDermott, and
Robert Poynter—was charged
with rewriting the original
document in the form of a
constitution and improving the
clarity and feasibility of some of
its provisions.
The major change made by the
group was the elimination of a
degree scale for academic
violations. Under the revised
version, penalties are set at the
discretion of the hearing board

See CLARITY, page 7

Graduate enrollment continues to decline
While the University's
undergraduate student body has
been steadily growing for the
past several years, graduate
student enrollment has
plummeted over the same peribd
of time, a trend which has given
some Hopkins administrators and
faculty cause for concern.
The number of graduate
students has gone down from a
high of 1309 in the Fall 1969
semester to the present
enrollment of936.
Though Homewood's
department chairmen contend
that the decrease has not had any
adverse impact on graduate
programs, research, or
undergraduate instruction, some
have expressed concern for the
trend's long term implications.
The downward spiral arises in
large part from the loss of a
substantial amount of
government funds for graduate
study over the past four years.
Most of the government's
Training Grant fellowships for

graduate study, as well as
numerous National Science
Foundation and National
Institute of Health subsidy
programs, have been terminated.
"The drop in graduate
enrollment is directly
attributable to the drying up of
government money," said Larry
Denton, director of Academic
Services. "In the heyday of
contracts and fellowships,
Hopkins could afford to
subsidize loads of graduate-level
educations. That's no longer
possible."
While numerous Homewood
departments operated with
Training Grants several years ago,
only four—Social Relations,
Psychology, Biology, and
Physics—have survived the
government cutbacks with their
grants intact.
Most departments, however,
appear able to cope with the
reduction in graduate students.
Dr. Willis Gore, Chairman of
Electrical Engineering, said that

faculty members in his
department have "picked up the
slack" in regard to undergraduate
section teaching, which is
normally the duty of graduate
students.
"In a conscientious
department, the faculty will help
make ends meet," he explained.
"We have not been adversely
affected by the overall drop in
enrollment, though we may if
this trend continues."
Dr. Brown Murr, head of
Chemistry, said that his
department's graduate programs
have not been impaired by
reduced enrollment, since the
size of the Chemistry faculty
itself has gone down from 22 to
18 in recent years. "We have less
graduate students than before,
but this was a deliberate decision
on the part of our faculty, to go
along with the reduction in our
full-time faculty, he explained.
Murr said that undergraduate
Chemistry majors are now being
used as lab assistants, a position

formerly reserved for graduate
students.
Murr and Gore both said that
they fear faculty members may
someday have to "pick up the
slack" of undergraduate teaching
at the expense of their research,
if the downward trend in
enrollment continues. "This is a
trend which should give all
faculty members cause to wonder
about the coming years in higher
education," Gore stated.
In their efforts to maintain a
stable enrollment despite the loss
of federal funds, departments are
trying to enroll more graduate
students capable of paying their
own tuition, according to Dean
of Arts and Sciences George
Owen.
Owen asserted, though, that
the financial status of an
applicant will not affect his
chances for graduate admission.
"We've been getting more paying
students because we've been
trying to force more of them to
pay their own way," he said.

COMMUNITY NEWS

City Fair: better than ever, but not necessarily bigger
Over one and a half million
people are expected to flock to
the Inner Harbor this weekend to
take part in the sixth annual
Baltimore City Fair.
Volunteers from 72
neighborhood associations, 115
non-profit organizations, and 15
ethnic groups will be on hand to
welcome and entertain* the
throngs that will pack the Harbor
area at Pratt and Light Streets.
In addition to the many
volunteer organizations that will
be present, professional
entertainment will also be
Provided during the weekend
festivities. Concerts, featuring
Two Generations of Brubeck,
Barbara McNair, and the
Maynard Ferguson Big Band will
be offered throughout the three
days, as well as performances by
the U.S. Army Golden Knights
Parachute Team and the Flying
Bilros.
The Fair hours are noon to 10
p.m. Friday, 10 a.m. to 10 p.m.
Saturday, and noon to 10 p.m.
Sunday. Admission is $1.25.
A park and ride service
operated by the MTA will be
Operated from three locations in

the city. The lower parking lot
on Wyman Park Drive and
Remington Avenue will serve as
one of the Park and Ride
stations. Buses will run at 20
minute intervals from the parking
lot to the Fair and back.
As in past years, Hopkins will
have an exhibit at the fair.
Volunteers from various
organizations will talk to
fairgoers about the activities at
the Hopkins institutions.
The theme for the Hopkins
exhibit is the University's
Centennial. A wood mobile
representing the Hopkins
commemorative Centennial
Crystal will hang 26 feet in the
air over the Hopkins exhibit. The
free-swinging mobile was
designed by Theo Anderson of
the Accent Display Company.
The Hopkins exhibit will be
located on the Fairgrounds near
the McCormick Spice Building.
At the request of the Fair
committee, Hopkins will also set
up five water fountains on tile
fairground, as it did last year.
According to Dea Kline,
Director of Community Affairs,
"Hopkins has always been very

supportive of the fair concept."
Kline, who continues to serve
on the Fair steering committee as
she has in the past, said that
Hopkins was the first institution
to sign-up for the Fair this year.
Kline asserted that this year
people from all over the East
Coast are likely to attend, many
to observe the Fair and bring
back ideas for sponsoring similar
fairs in their own cities and
communities.

necessarily bigger," Kline said.
Last year's crowds of over one
and a half million taxed the
limits of the Fairground's
capacity.

So until the necessity of a tuition hike—of any
The Committee's chairman,

Moreover, we stand opposed not only because of the proposal was "rather strict."
hardship a tuition hike would inflict on present students, but Indeed. Calling that thing "rather
because of the detrimental long-range effects such a move strict'' is an act of
understatement akin to calling

tuition

would have on the University.
Most important, the school would be pr4cing itself out of
the market of higher .education. True, Hopkins would still be
in the same price range as Harvard,.Yale, etc., but will have
realistically placed itself out of the reach of. many people.
Even more so than today, a Hopkins education will only be
available to the student who is willing to make an
extraordinary financial commitment.
It seems incongrous that an institution such as Hopkins
which prides itself in being unique in so many ways would
fail to remain unique on this crucial point: accessibility to
anyone interested in serious learning.
We are convinced that there are long-range as well as
short-term methods to avoid a tuition hike. Solutions such as
ancillary personnel cutbacks, cutbacks in the more frivolous t
student services. iind the establishment of a tuition
endowment must be considered to prevent Hopkins 1,
froingoing
Auschwitz "a shame".
The Council didn't like the
proposal. Nor did Dean Suskind,
to whose office it entrusted a
host of piddling responsibilities
better suited to a Liverpool
truant officer than to the
University's second highest
academic administrator.
What's more, the thing wasn't
legally viable. University lawyers
advised that Hopkins could well
be entrenched in litigation until
its Tricentennial if that proposal
ever got through. And to be sure,
the Dean's Office had had
enough legal hassles with the
supposedly air-tight Honor
System. So, not wanting the ghost
of Blackstone himself to descend
on Homewood House, Suskind
told the committee to go back to
the Student Council.
The Student Council told the
committee to go out and get
some proof Faculty weren't too
happy about having a venerable
old institution done away with
by some self-appointed student
inquisitors on the basis of a vague
and unsubstantiated "feeling"
that cheating had reached
dangerous proportions. And get
proof they did.
Poll
The committee, on its two
week research furlough,
conducted an anonymous poll of
students in large science survey
courses, which asked the
students, among other questions,
if they had ever cheated on an
exam at Hopkins. The results
were staggering. A terribly high,
embarrassingly high percentage
admitted to having cheated. The
Baltimore Sun picked up on it.
The News American picked up
on it. Faculty members spoke in
hushed tones of the demise of
the Honor System.
One member of the Physics
faculty reportedly suggested that
all the students who had
confessed to cheating be
apprehended and penalized
appropriately. It was pointed out
that the survey was anoymous,
and that no matter how
sophisticated the techniques of
detection, the handwriting on the
ballots would surely not admit of
any conclusive deducation
concerning individuality.
One member of the committee
theorized that perhaps the
students who had admitted to
cheating were not really guilty.
Was not confession akin to
absolution, he inquired. Were
they really guilty?
Yeah, they were guilty; guilty
as hell. So the Student Council

had proof on its hands—along
with 2, alarmed faculty
members who were demanding
that the governance for academic
offenses be revised with alacrity.
So the Student Council sent out
a new committee, comprised of
most of the members of the old
committee and some interested
and respected professors, to find
a viable alternative to the Honor
System. The rhetoric of the new
committee abounded with such
terms as viability, feasibility,
legality, effectuality, and
integrity.
This was to be an efficient
committee which would produce
an acceptable alternative, and
with due haste. For the end of
school was waxing near, and the
whole matter would have to be
put to student referendum before
summer recess. So the new
committee burnt the midnight oil
to come up with an alternative
before the end of the semester.
And they did it. And it went to
student referendum. And the
students passed it. And all was
"as it was before..."
Except that it just wouldn't
do. The proposal was too ragged,
too vague in regard to legal
technicalities; in general, too
hastily compiled. It would have
to be rewritten. So the Student
Council and the Academic
Council, which was by now
immersed in the turmoil, sent out
a "task force" to rewrite the
document.
So eight good students and
professors did spend their
summer and early fall working on
the alternative, perhaps
wondering occasionally whence
the need for this effort had
sprang.
But now that they're done, the
document will have to go back to
student referendum, because it's
a different document than the
one the students passed last
spring.
And it's precisely here that a
harrowing possibility arises.
Suppose the students don't pass
it. Suppose out of ignorance,
disinterest, or sheer funk, they
vote it down. Then those six
months of work. which began so
unportentously back in February
with a two-week committee, will
have been for naught!!
Should the referendum pass or
not:this week's vote will dispose
at one stroke of the controversy
and concern over the alternative
to the Honor System. And when
it's all over, Gilman Hall itself
will likely heave an audible sigh
of relief

By GEORGE B. ZELINSKY
Sunday, Andy Warhol came to
town—to close the exhibit he
didn't see, to plug the book he
didn't really care about and to
kick-off the tour he wishes he
didn't have to be on. He hated to

two-hour interview were Warhol's
revelations that Chelsea Girls was
his only film that he likes; there
has been no modern art since the
impressionists ("...just a lot of
photographs."; he thinks he'll be
remembered for the Campbell's
Soup can ("...that's about all.");
his ambition is to have a
television special (in the works,
it'll be called "Nothing Special");
his strongest emotional
experience o ccured Sunday
morning (he decided to leave
Archie behind—can you believe
that?); and that he liked
President Ford a lot, but he liked
Jack Ford better.

Looking as though he
desperately wanted to be
somewhere else (probably with
Archie), Warhol held up well
under the barrage of inane,
empty, and often thoughtless
questions. Buttressed on the right

cp

leave Archie behind (Andy's
faithful canine companion—"...he
has great table manners.") but
when the publisher says you
gotta move—you gotta move.
No matter. The first stop was
Charm City and after a frenetic
book-signing session in the lobby
of the Baltimore Museum of Art,
the entourage was whisked off to
the Cross Keys Inn, to hold court
for the press.

by Bob Colacello, major-domo of
Warhol's Interview magazine, and
on the left by Lady Anne
Lambton, a follower who
primarily distinguished herself
with a deafening laught and a
barely intelligible British accent
("Well, reylly Ahndy..."), Warhol
propped himself up on a dresser
and allowed his supporting cast
to do most of the talking.

More Balto history:
A few hot ideas
Go West!
But it would be uncharitable
to say that Johns Hopkins did his
City no good at all. Some say it
was the influence of the old
humbug that prevailed upon the
leaders of the Democratic party
to give Baltimore a break. In any
case, the Democratic convention
was held here in 1872. Horace
Greeley, who didn't coin the
Phrase "Go West, young man"
but rather managed to run it into
the ground, took the nomination.
Inspired by Horace's famous
cliche, which he managed to
work somehow into (Lis
acceptance speech, fifty delegates
walked out of the convention
hall and started to go west. After
a fifteen-mile Iiike,they tired and
decided to stay put on the spot
where they wound up. Such was
the founding of the town of
Catonsville, Maryland. Horace,
despite all the hoopla of the
convention and the defection to
his side of a segment of the
Republican party, didn't do too
well against Grant in the general
election. The fact that Horace
died before the election was held
probably had something to do
with a lot of people voting for
Grant, who, if not very astute
politically, was still "viable", so
to speak. Of course, Greeley's
Premature demise was attributed
back to the Baltimore jinx;
Baltimore was again out of
business as Convention City,
U.S.A. and stayed that way until
1912, when ex-Hoppie Woodrow
Wilson got the nod at the
mother-ugly Fifth Regiment
Armory on Preston Street. You
can go home again. The questior
remains: Why would anybody

want to?
Vale, Baltimore
The Panic of 1873, following
close behind the death of
Greeley, devastated Baltimore
businesses. Desperate times
brought forth desperate schemes.
Urban historian James Breslin has
recently discovered the diary of
Baltimore mayor Ferdinand
Latrobe, in which the mayor
describes how a professional
arsonist, Marvin the Torch, gave
the city council the idea for the
-Great Baltimore Fire. "There's
no way business will improve,.'
Marvin told the people's
representatives. "You better cut
your losses while you can and
collect your insurance money.
That's where I come in. You see
this central business
district—(Marvin pointed out the
window of City Hall)—I'm gonna
take it and build you an empty
lot!"
Marvin's proposal was relayed
to the Board of Estimates, which
body decided the Torch's price
was too high. The city would be
better off hiring a local amateur
to do the job on the city. The
Board's recommendation was
sent back to the council for
debate in the summer of 1875.
After extensive debate, the city
fathers decided upon a plan of
action. It was now 1904—five
other depressions had since made
their mark since Greeley's
Revenge. I hate to end on an

Shy, diminuative, looking
every bit the Choate lad, Warhol
was occasionally put off by the
sometimes insensitive and hostile
questions aimed at him by the
bizarre cast assembled in his
suite. He was somewhat amused
by a microphone-flourishing
woman from PBS Radio (well
lubricated by several glasses of
the complimentary Paul Masson
Chablis), who was strikingly
reminiscent of Opal, the
incredibly shallow British
journalist who plagued Altman's
Nashville. She seemed intent on
tell ing Warhol about Warhol,
Baltimore, herself, his Jockey
shorts and other less notable
landmarks. The woman made a
legitimate attempt at contesting
Edith Massey (also known as
Divine, from Pink Flamingos and
Female Trouble) for the
distinction of being the strangest
woman Warhol ever met.
Warhol's future clans had

included a low-budget movie and
two more books. However, the
movie (tentatively titled Bad
Women) suffered a set-back when
his financial supporter walked
out, two days ago. The movie
will go on, with Warhol
producing. Terming all of his
work as "entertainment", Warhol
reiterated his belief in art as
entertainment.
The token Warhol cultist in

attendance asked Andy to
display his now highly publicized
scars (the result of a near-fatal
shooting), but Warhol demurred,
offering "some nice
photographs" instead.
Looking fatigued towards the
end, Warhol commented that
"Archie probably would have
made a better interview."

Andy Warhol.

Eisenhower Library
operating new system
The clarity•••is vastly improved'
Early in September the
Eisenhower Library began
Operating its new computerized
circulation system. The system
consists of a minicomputer,
keyboard display units (CRTs)
and light-pen terminals for
recording charges and discharges.
Each book which circulates will
have affixed to it a bar-encoded
label which, through the
computer data base, records the
essential information about the
volume. In addition another label
on the patron's ID card records
information about that user.
In order to charge out a book
the user presents his or her ID
card and the books wanted at the
Circulation Desk. The light pen is
then drawn over the labels and all
information necessary to charge
the book is thus recorded in the
system and instantly retrievable.

Much the same process is
followed in discharging books
except that reservations or
"holds" for other readers are
automatically signalled by the
terminals.
Advantages
There are several advantages to
the system including more
up-to-date inforrn'ation on the
status of the books, a better
system for reserving books for
other readers, improved security,
and lower cost. The transition
between systems, however, is not
an easy one and has caused some
delay at the Circulation Desk.
Although the staff has
"converted" over 60,000
volumes for use through the new
system, other volumes have to be
converted on the spot by
photocopying of title pages and
recording of call numbers.

"We were torn as to how much

The task force also made
semantic changes to improve the
document's clarity as well as its
legal viability. On the
recommendations of the
University's general counsel, the
panel was forced to make
changes in the proposal last week
just prior to its submission to the
SC and the Academic Council.
Integrity
The essential provisons of the
Code have not been altered. The
student-faculty "Academic
Integrity Board" is still charged
with maintaining "the academic
integrity of the Johns Hopkins
University in all respects."
As in the original document,
proctoring is an optional stricture
which may be invoked by faculty

Joachim Blunck

at their own discretion or at the
request of students. Students are
encouraged, though not required,
to report offenses to the Review
Board.
"The clarity of the proposal is
vastly improved and the penalties
are much more clearly
expressed," commented Suskind.
"The absence of a strong punitive
tone gives me a feeling that this is
a damn good document and that
it will work."
SC President Mike Lenardo
also considers the Code an
effective method of governance,
and much improved from its
original state.
Said Holik, "I support the
document, though I feel that it
represents a lot of compromise."

Hopkins eleven bow in scrimmage marred by death
By STEPHEN LEVIN
The Hopkins football team
gained their first taste of
inter-collegiate action, when
Coach Dennis Cox's gridders
travelled to Lebanon Valley on
Saturday for a scrimmage with
the Flying Dutchmen.
The contest took on a
somewhat eerie glow and the
game itself became somewhat
secondary when tragedy struck
near the end of the first quarter.

One of the officials suddenly
collapsed and died on the field,
having suffered -a heart attack.
Despite the pall which this cast
over the action, the game
continued and the
Pennsylvanians emerged
victorious, outscoring the Blue
Jays three touchdowns to two, in
a game played under simulated
game conditions which excluded
kick-offs and returns.
"At this point I would say that

we are definitely stronger
offensively and defensively,"
noted Coach Cox. "We have a lot
more returning people on offense
and a lot more holes to fill on
defense."
The Jays use a multiple
offense with sophomore Dave
Emala at the helm.
"In our offense the
quarterback has to be able to run
as well as throw," said Cox,"and
Dave can do that. He hasn't quite

Rooters take five out offive
By DAVID KRAUS
The JHU Varsity soccer team
upped their pre-season record to
8-2-1 by defeating five area
opponents this past weekend.
The Blue Jay booters began
their successes Friday afternoon
with a 6-1 decision over Dundalk
Community College and closed
out Sunday with four
consecutive victories at the Essex
Community College Soccer
Festival.
Friday's contest was played at
Homewood on a rain-soaked
field. The home team starters
included goalie Greg Bradley,
defensemen Ami Cohen, Frank
Olszewski and Lou Podrazik,
. midfielders Gary Ignatowski,
Tom Myrick and Bob Teasd ale,
and a forward line of Steve
Galloway, Joe Rutkowski, Greg
Cunningham and Larry
McGowan.,
Hopkins took early command
of the game and scored the first
goal midway through the first
period. McGowan, playing left
wing, centered the ball toCunningham, who shot it past
the goalie.
The rest of the first half was
closely played with both teams
having good opportunities, but
failing to cash in on them.
The Blue Jays broke the game
open in the third quarter, scoring

three times while holding their
visitors to a lone goal.
Ken Seuss scored what proved
to be the game winner just five
minutes into the third stanza
when he looped one over the
Dundalk netminder. The visitors
got their only tally of the day a
minute later when a penalty shot
trickled off the hands of goalie
Bradley and into the net.
Coach Robert Oliver's charges
put the game out of reach with
two quick goals at the end of the
period. Rutkowski and
Cunningham scored within three
minutes of each other, the latter
coming with just twenty seconds
remaining in the quarter.
A brief melee occured early in
the final period and a frustrated
Dundalk defenseman was asked
to leave the game. Myrick and
Galloway then proceeded to put
the final nails in the Dundalk
coffin, tallying the final two Blue
Jay goals.
Coach Oliverssaid that it was
"good to play under these lousy
conditions. This is the type of
thing we'll face during the regular
season and it's nice to get used to
it now."
By contrast, Sunday was a
beautiful day, but the game
results were equally favorable for
the Homewood booters.

Tennis team looking
towards strong year
By JOHN GIGLIO
When you talk to Coach Joyce
Hogan these days about how the
Hopkins' Women's tennis team is
shaping up, she'll nod and break
into a smile.
Why? One word: talent.
This year's racquet-wielding
Blue Jays are loaded \Mill it.
They'll be heading into MAC and
MA IAW League competition
with a solid nucleus of
experienced veterans plus a
surprisingly well-schooled bunch
of hard-playing freshmen.
All five starting singles players
from last year's team: Cathy
Cramer, Sandy Ciciora, Susan
Thomas, Lisa Kuhar, and Gwen
Pavlovitz are back to hammer
away at the likes of Goucher and
Franklin and Mafshall, to of
Hopkins' toughest opponents.
Joining them will be a host of
first year players. Three that
really shine on the courts are
Kate Foster, Beth Yanowitz, and
Nancy Tang. Their coach is
especially high on them because
of their outstanding play and
skills displayed so far during

practice along with their fine
records as high school and
tournament players. Two other
girls that have caught the coach's
eye with their strong doubles
play are Lisa Turgell and Anne
Caston.
Positions
The team has been working
out every day since Sept. 8 and
because of the large number of
experienced and talented players
the team carries, Coach Hogan
has said she has "been able to
concentrate more on the strategy
of each individual player's game,
along with setting up shots and
positioning for the doubles
candidates."
We will soon see just how
strong their play is for their first
match is scheduled for this
Thursday, Sept. 18 at home, 4
pm against Notre Dame.
Although declining when
asked to make any predictions,
Coach Hogan's enthusiasm and
optimism was unmistakable. A
seasoned group of veterans
together with a batch of bright
young players spells WINNER!

Lax stars to shine Saturday
The Third Annual Super Star
Lacrosse game will be held on
Homewood Field Saturday, Sept.
20 at 8:30 pm., giving
newcomers to Hopkins their first
look at the mightiest of sports at
Homewood. The game is being
organized by the Lacrosse
Foundation, formerly known as
the Hall of Fame.
The best of the colleges will
challenge the best of the clubs in
this charity contest, the proceeds
of which will go to the Lacrosse
Foundation. In the past, funds
have been used to send players to
the World Series of Lacrosse held
in Australia in 1974. The next
World Series is scheduled for
Manchester, England in 1978.
Among the collegiates will be
three members of the Blue Jay
ten. Attackmen Franz

Wittelsberger and Mike O'Neil
along with goalie Kevin Mahon
will represent Hopkins.
The clubmen will be trying to
capture their first victory in this
seric, having dropped both of
the previous contests.
Tix
Tickets for adults are $3.00 at
the gate and $2.00 in advance.

Children's tickets are $2.00 at
the door and $1.00 in advance.
All tickets can be purchased from
the Lacrosse Foundation which is
located in the Lacrosse Hall of
Fame in the Newton H. White
Athletic Center; as well as at
Bacharach-Rasin, Triangle, and
STX sporting good stores and at
the Crease Restaurant in Towson.
